t: For the choir director: on the Gittith. Of Asaph.
Sing*pn for joy to God our strength; shout*ln in triumph to the God of Jacob.
Lift*ln up a song — play the tambourine, the*ln melodious lyre, and the harp.
Blow*ln the ram’s horn on the day of our feasts during*ln the new moon and*ln during the full moon.
For*ln this is a statute for Israel, an*ln ordinance of the God of Jacob.
He*ln set it up as a decree for Joseph when*ln he went throughout the land of Egypt. I*ln heard an unfamiliar language:
“I*ln relieved his shoulder from the burden; his*ln hands were freed from carrying the basket.
You*ln called out in distress, and I rescued you; I*ln answered you from the thundercloud. I*ln tested you at the Waters of Meribah. Selah*ig
Listen,*ln my people, and I will admonish you. Israel,*ln if you would only listen to me!
There*ln must not be a strange god among you; you*ln must not bow down to a foreign god.
I*ln am the Lord*s your God, who*ln brought you up from the land of Egypt. Open*ln your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
“But*pn my people did not listen to my voice; Israel*ln did not obey me.
So*ln I gave them over to their stubborn hearts to*ln follow their own plans.
If*ln only my people would listen to me and*ln Israel would follow my ways,
I*ln would quickly subdue their enemies and*ln turn my hand against their foes.”
Those*ln who hate the Lord*s would*ln cower to him; their*ln doom would last forever.
But*ln he would feed Israel with the best wheat. “I*ln would satisfy you with honey from the rock.”
